headline.main: After Defeat, Journey to Uncertain Fate

lead_paragraph: Like some lost caravan, the trucks rumbled across the steppe bearing their wretched cargo, 800 Taliban prisoners bound for an uncertain fate. The prisoners, crawling and writhing on one another like turtles in a pet shop, were the sorry byproduct of the Northern Alliance's most recent victory. Until Monday, the Taliban soldiers had been hunkered down in the northern city of Kunduz, and when the Northern Alliance laid siege to the place for the last two weeks, the Taliban troops faced the choice of surrendering or fighting to the death. First they retreated, then they gave up.
abstract: Trucks crammed with foreign Taliban prisoners captured by Northern Alliance Gen Abdul Rashid Dostum outside Kunduz, Afghanistan, wait in Khulm for word on final destination; fate of foreign prisoners is murky, with alliance commanders bickering over whether they should be tried and executed or turned over to United Nations; trucks were bound for fortress that is now site of prisoner uprising; prisoners are mostly Pakistanis; photo (M)
